data.title: Judo at The 2024 Paris Olympics: The Ones to Watch
data.meta_description: No matter what a judoka has accomplished in terms of their placements at Opens, Grand Slams, Masters and World Championships, the biggest bill on the receipt of their international career will always be their time at the Olympic Games.
data.text:
Note: Unfamiliar with the rules of Judo? You can find a quick run down of the rules linked here (the Olympic broadcast will also explain them throughout the event so no need to fear!).

No matter what a judoka has accomplished in terms of their placements at Opens, Grand Slams, Masters and World Championships, the biggest bill on the receipt of their international career will always be their time at the Olympic Games. It is such a historically significant event that those who do not deem it to be the highest level of competition are surrounded by perked ears and near interrogative questions. While this argument does hold weight (a quantifiable amount of elite judoka will not be competing at the games*), the dream for all competitors has always been the Olympic gold medal, and I doubt that is going to change in the coming years.

I don’t write this as a means of predicting who will win. I’m pretty bad at predicting things in general, and that applies to judo two-fold. Instead, this will act as a general guide for those newer to the sport of judo who want to watch it at Paris, as well as being a bite sized recap of the best performing judoka heading into the games for avid viewers who may have missed or forgotten results. Either way, I’ve picked a small group of athletes from each category who have proven their ability to perform and…
